author: Andrew Gregory
title: After Mo Farah's drugs confession what are the effects of the banned drug khat?
text:
Khat is a leafy plant which acts as a stimulant when you chew its bitter leaves.
It is supposed to make you more alert and raise your energy levels. Its advocates say it is as harmless as coffee or tea.
But last year it became a controlled class C drug in the UK. This means it’s illegal to have khat for yourself and to sell or give away khat to someone else.
It’s known to many as qaat - especially in Somalia, where Mo Farah was born. In his autobiography, Twin Ambitions, Farah says: “All grown-up Somalis chew this stuff.
“Some people see it as a drug, although for Somalis and Muslims generally, it’s a social thing, like drinking coffee or having a beer in a pub in England.”
PA Winner: Mo Farah of Britain celebrates winning the men's 5,000 metres final during the 15th IAAF World Championships
The two main stimulants in khat quicken up the pace of your mind and body, like a less powerful version of amphetamine, which is known as speed.
It can make you more alert, happy and talkative but can cause insomnia and temporary confusion.
Video loading
If you chew it for a few hours it can leave you with a feeling of calm, described by some as feeling blissed out.
It can also suppress your appetite.
Getty Victory: Mo Farah celebrates winning the final of the men's 5000 metres athletics event
But experts warn the drug could make pre-existing mental health problems worse, and can cause paranoid and psychotic reactions.
It can also spark feelings of anxiety and aggression .
Khat can also inflame your mouth and damage your teeth, and there are concerns about the long-term risk of mouth cancers.
AFP Olympian: Mo Farah of Britain celebrates winning the men's 5,000 metres final during the 15th IAAF World Championships
You can also get high blood pressure, heart palpitations and heart problems with heavy use.
As khat can cause periods of increased libido, care may be needed to minimise the risk of unsafe sex and unwanted pregnancies.
Getty National treasure: Mo Farah does his 'mobot' celebration after winning the final of the men's 5000 metres athletics event at the 2015 IAAF World Championships
If caught with khat in the UK, you face being arrested and could end up spending two years in prison and/or an unlimited fine. Selling khat or giving khat away for free, even to your friends - known as supplying - could result in up to 14 years in jail and/or an unlimited fine.
